soba_userInput: create an alternative mind map for baroque music, better organised, and completing the missing information of the model
soba_metaModelContext:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ecore:EPackage xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:ecore="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore" name="mindMap" nsURI="http://mindmap/0.1" nsPrefix="map">
  <eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="Map">
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="name">
      <eType xsi:type="ecore:EDataType" href="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/>
    </eStructuralFeatures>
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="description">
      <eType xsi:type="ecore:EDataType" href="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/>
    </eStructuralFeatures>
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="root" eType="//Concept" containment="true"/>
  </eClassifiers>
  <eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="Concept">
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="name">
      <eType xsi:type="ecore:EDataType" href="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/>
    </eStructuralFeatures>
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="subConcepts" upperBound="-1" eType="//Concept" containment="true" eOpposite="//Concept/parent"/>
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="parent" eType="//Concept" eOpposite="//Concept/subConcepts"/>
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="description">
      <eType xsi:type="ecore:EDataType" href="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/>
    </eStructuralFeatures>
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="relatedTo" upperBound="-1" eType="//Concept"/>
  </eClassifiers>
</ecore:EPackage>

subConcepts.name: Key Developments
subConcepts.description: Introduction of basso continuo, monody, and the first operas.

subConcepts.name: Key Composers
subConcepts.description: Monteverdi, Gabrieli, Schütz.

subConcepts.name: Early Baroque
subConcepts.description: c. 1600–1650. Marked by the development of opera and new harmonic styles.

subConcepts.name: Key Developments
subConcepts.description: Establishment of major instrumental forms (concerto, sonata), rise of national styles.

subConcepts.name: Key Composers
subConcepts.description: Lully, Purcell, Corelli, Buxtehude.

subConcepts.name: Middle Baroque
subConcepts.description: c. 1650–1700. Instrumental music solidified, and opera spread across Europe.

subConcepts.name: Key Developments
subConcepts.description: Peak of fugal writing, development of the solo concerto, grand oratorios.

subConcepts.name: Key Composers
subConcepts.description: Bach, Handel, Vivaldi, Telemann, Rameau.

subConcepts.name: Late Baroque
subConcepts.description: c. 1700–1750. The culmination of Baroque style, featuring complex counterpoint and grand forms.

subConcepts.name: Historical Context
subConcepts.description: The evolution and periods within Baroque music.

subConcepts.name: Origins
subConcepts.description: Developed in Italy around 1600, influenced by Greek drama.

subConcepts.name: Key Elements
subConcepts.description: Recitative, Aria, Chorus, Libretto.

subConcepts.name: Common Themes
subConcepts.description: Mythological, historical, and heroic subjects.

subConcepts.name: Opera
subConcepts.description: A staged musical drama, combining singing, acting, and orchestral accompaniment.

subConcepts.name: Oratorio
subConcepts.description: A large-scale musical work for orchestra and chorus, typically on a sacred theme, but not staged.

subConcepts.name: Cantata
subConcepts.description: A vocal composition with instrumental accompaniment, typically in several movements.

subConcepts.name: Choral Music
subConcepts.description: Sacred and secular choral works, including masses and motets.

subConcepts.name: Vocal Music
subConcepts.description: Music for the voice, often with instrumental accompaniment.

subConcepts.name: Concerto Grosso
subConcepts.description: Features a small group of soloists (concertino) contrasted with the full orchestra (ripieno).

subConcepts.name: Solo Concerto
subConcepts.description: Features a single solo instrument.

subConcepts.name: Concerto
subConcepts.description: A musical composition usually featuring a solo instrument or a small group of soloists accompanied by an orchestra.

subConcepts.name: Sonata da Chiesa
subConcepts.description: Church sonata, usually with a more serious and stately character.

subConcepts.name: Sonata da Camera
subConcepts.description: Chamber sonata, often a suite of dances.

subConcepts.name: Sonata
subConcepts.description: An instrumental composition, typically of several movements.

subConcepts.name: Typical Movements
subConcepts.description: Allemande, Courante, Sarabande, Gigue (often with optional dances like Minuet, Bourrée).

subConcepts.name: Dance Suite
subConcepts.description: A collection of instrumental dances, typically preceded by a prelude or overture.

subConcepts.name: Fugue
subConcepts.description: A contrapuntal compositional technique in two or more voices, built on a central theme (subject).

subConcepts.name: Prelude
subConcepts.description: An instrumental composition that is introductory in character.

subConcepts.name: Toccata
subConcepts.description: A virtuosic piece of music for keyboard instruments, typically with a free and rhapsodic style.

subConcepts.name: Instrumental Music
subConcepts.description: Music composed for instruments, often with intricate textures and virtuosity.

subConcepts.name: Genres & Forms
subConcepts.description: Major musical forms and categories developed or popularized during the Baroque era.

subConcepts.name: Texture
subConcepts.description: Predominantly polyphonic (especially late Baroque) and homophonic (early Baroque, opera).

subConcepts.name: Harmony
subConcepts.description: Development of tonal harmony, functional harmony, and chromaticism.

subConcepts.name: Melody
subConcepts.description: Often elaborate, sequential, and based on short, recurring motifs.

subConcepts.name: Rhythm
subConcepts.description: Steady, driving rhythms with clear meter and often motoric (energetic) quality.

subConcepts.name: Dynamics
subConcepts.description: Terraced dynamics (sudden shifts between loud and soft) rather than gradual crescendos/decrescendos.

subConcepts.name: Timbre
subConcepts.description: Richness of instrumental color; development of the orchestra; contrast between soloists and ensemble.

subConcepts.name: Ornamentation
subConcepts.description: Extensive use of trills, mordents, appoggiaturas, and other embellishments to add expressiveness and virtuosity.

subConcepts.name: Basso Continuo
subConcepts.description: A continuous bass line played by a keyboard instrument (harpsichord, organ) and a low string instrument (cello, bassoon), providing harmonic foundation.

subConcepts.name: Key Characteristics
subConcepts.description: Defining musical elements and stylistic features of the Baroque era.

subConcepts.name: Keyboard Instruments
subConcepts.description: Harpsichord, Organ, Clavichord.

subConcepts.name: String Instruments
subConcepts.description: Violin family (violin, viola, cello, double bass), Viola da gamba family, Lute.

subConcepts.name: Woodwind Instruments
subConcepts.description: Recorder, Baroque flute, Oboe, Bassoon.

subConcepts.name: Brass Instruments
subConcepts.description: Natural trumpet, Natural horn, Sackbut.

subConcepts.name: Percussion Instruments
subConcepts.description: Timpani, Kettle drums (less common in chamber music).

subConcepts.name: Prominent Instruments
subConcepts.description: Key instruments that defined the Baroque sound.

root.name: Baroque Music
root.description: The period in Western classical music from roughly 1600 to 1750, characterized by grandeur, drama, and elaborate ornamentation.

recommendationPayload.name: Baroque Music - Comprehensive Overview
recommendationPayload.description: An alternative, more detailed mind map of Baroque music, aiming for better organization and completeness.
